I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  contribute  to  improved 
evidence-based decision-making by Uzbekistan’s Ministry of Economic Development and Poverty 
Reduction (MOEDPR) in its response to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. The TA 
is  designed  to  support  the  MOEDPR’s  stabilization  measures,  triggered  by  the  COVID-19 
pandemic, and to complement them with targeted institutional strengthening of the MOEDPR in 
the medium term. 
 
2.  On 7 May 2020, the MOEDPR requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
technical  support  along  the  following  strategic  lines:  (i)  preparing  a  socioeconomic  impact 
assessment  of  the  COVID-19  pandemic  in  the  country,  (ii)  developing  a  socioeconomic 
development concept (Vision 2030), (iii) formulating approaches to industrial policy development, 
and (iv) facilitating longer term institutional strengthening of the MOEDPR. This proposed TA is 
aligned with the ongoing country partnership strategy and the country knowledge plan.1  
 
II.  ISSUES   
 
3.  Uncertainty  over  duration  and  spread  of  COVID-19.  On  15 March  2020,  the 
government  announced  the first  confirmed case  of  COVID-19  in  Uzbekistan.  The  rigorous 
lockdown measures, including the quarantine of all suspected cases and contacts, helped reduce 
the 5-day moving average of daily new confirmed COVID-19 cases from more than 100 in mid-
April to less than 50 by the end of April 2020, further through the month of May until mid-June. 
However, the gradual relaxation of lockdown measures and the repatriation of thousands of 
Uzbek migrant workers have caused the infection rate to rise from the latter half of June, with the 
5-day moving average of new confirmed COVID-19 cases spiking to about 500 daily since mid-
July 2020.2 By 27 July 2020, a total of 20,531 COVID-19 cases and 116 deaths had been 
confirmed.3 The  World  Health  Organization  (WHO)  estimates  that  the  weekly  number  of 
confirmed cases could plateau at more than 8,000 by January 2021.4 Given the uncertainty, the 
country needs to reinforce its resilience to COVID-19 and other public health emergencies.   
  
4.  Projected  economic  slowdown  and  economic  impact  in  2020.  The  COVID-19 
pandemic has caused significant negative macroeconomic impacts in the region. However, while 
most  economies  worldwide,  including  some  in  the  region,  are  expected  to  contract,  the 
International Monetary Fund projects gross domestic product growth in Uzbekistan to decelerate 
to 1.5% in 2020 compared with the pre-COVID-19 growth estimate of 6.0%. With the lowering of 
budget revenues, increasing health and social expenditures, and rise in countercyclical funding, 
the financing gap is estimated at $3.4 billion (about 5.6% of gross domestic product) in 2020. The 
government announced anti-crisis measures on 19 March, 3 April, and 18 May 2020, covering 
health, inclusive social protection, and stimulus measures for domestic enterprises. The aims of 
the anti-crisis measures were to provide a medical response for the early identification and 
containment of the infection, limit negative effects on the incomes and livelihoods of the poorest 
sections of the population, minimize long-term adverse effects on the economy, and continue the 
government’s  reform  program  despite  the  COVID-19  disruption.  External  support  is  being

provided through the socioeconomic response and recovery package, prepared jointly by United

5.  Socioeconomic response and recovery program. The program covers seven priority 
areas: (i) providing support to essential health services, (ii) sustaining the macroeconomic 
response and recovery, (iii) deepening social protection, (iv) supporting workers and job creation, 
(v) improving education services, (vi) protecting vulnerable groups and social cohesion, and 
(vii) strengthening data and assessments. Development partners have committed to 176 activities, 
planned on an immediate (within 1 month), short-term (1–3 months), medium-term (3–6 months), 
or long-term (beyond 6 months) basis. Within this framework, ADB has programmed nine 
activities with a total resource envelope of $1.4 billion as of mid-June, covering both sovereign 
and nonsovereign support.  
 
6.  Restructuring of government ministries. The MOEDPR was created in March 2020, 
when the Ministry of Economy and Industry was restructured (before the outbreak of COVID-19 
in the country in mid-March). It has a mandate to be the government’s main ministry for developing 
policy  and  to  ensure  greater  coherence  between  economic  management  practices  and 
macroeconomic reforms, which the government has successfully implemented since early 2017. 
The  priorities  of  the  MOEDPR  include  catalyzing  entrepreneurship,  creating  decent  jobs, 
promoting private sector participation, and transitioning to a role to facilitate reforms. 
 
7.  Ongoing reconfiguration of roles and responsibilities. The MOEDPR will play a 
guiding role with reference to policies and strategies in the country’s socioeconomic development; 
state investments, liberalization, and structural reforms; the corporatization and modernization of 
state-owned enterprises (SOEs); industrial policy development; entrepreneurship; and gender-
sensitive poverty reduction. Given this mandate, the roles and responsibilities of various ministries 
and agencies (e.g., the MOEDPR, Ministry of Finance, State Asset Management Agency, and 
SOEs) are being reconfigured.   
 
8.  Build back better after COVID-19. Before COVID-19, the MOEDPR had 10 priority areas: 
(i) the development and implementation of macroeconomic policies, (ii) gender-sensitive poverty 
reduction,  (iii)  socioeconomic  development  of  the  country’s  regions,  (iv)  entrepreneurship, 
(v) approaches to industrial policy, (vi) SOE reforms, (vii) the implementation of a state investment 
policy, (viii) infrastructure development and urbanization, (ix) creating an enabling environment 
for business, and (x) relations with the Eurasian Economic Union. With the COVID-19 pandemic 
and the resulting macroeconomic and socioeconomic disruption, the MOEDPR has taken a 
“COVID-19  plus”  approach—including  the  economic  impact  of  the  health  consequences  of 
COVID-19—to understand the effects of these disruptions on its mandate and identify optimal 
ways to reconfigure policies and strategies.  
 
9.  Gender issues. The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbates vulnerability and inequality, and 
affects men and women in different ways. While men and women are equally likely to become 
infected by COVID-19, men have a higher risk of severe illness with a higher mortality rate than 
women. However, most frontline health service staff are women (about 80%), placing them at a 
higher occupational risk of contracting COVID-19. Women are more involved in micro-, family, 
and sole-proprietorship businesses, which have been affected by the reduced demand caused 
by the government lockdown and restrictions. Women are also disproportionally susceptible to 
 
5  United  Nations  Uzbekistan.  2020.  Consolidated  Value-Propositions  of  Multilateral  Development  Partners. 
Socioeconomic Response to Mitigate the Negative Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic. Tashkent.

increased instances of gender-based violence (GBV) and domestic violence.6 This increased 
insecurity is reflected in the rise in the number of cases of women who have reached out to crisis 
centers in the country.7 While these crisis centers remain functional, they also lack much-needed 
personal protective equipment for their staff, including women.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
  
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: strengthened economic management capacity 
of the MOEDPR. The TA will have the following outcome: improved evidence-based decision-
making by the MOEDPR in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, and increased institutional 
capacity in economic management.8  
 
11.  The TA is expected to enable the MOEDPR to (i) minimize the negative effects of the 
COVID-19 pandemic on Uzbekistan’s population, with a focus on women; and (ii) maximize the 
development results from economic management, and socioeconomic and poverty reduction 
efforts, which will be informed by the findings from knowledge products to be prepared through 
this TA. The increased management capacity of the MOEDPR is expected to facilitate further 
liberalization, and accelerate the country’s economic reforms.9  
 
12.  The TA activities will contribute to raise the MOEDPR management’s understanding of the 
depth and scale of the COVID-19 disruption in the country, as well as the regional perspective. It 
will support the development of knowledge products to ensure higher levels of coherence between 
economic management policies and macroeconomic reforms. The TA will enable the MOEDPR 
to position itself as the government’s policy anchor, catalyze change to limit the role of the State 
to facilitate growth, and promote private sector participation. TA activities will support structural 
reforms and institutional development, to create jobs and promote inclusive economic growth. 
The TA will also inform government efforts in addressing GBV during the crisis and putting in 
place various prevention mechanisms. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
13.  Three outputs are envisaged for the TA: (i) knowledge products and analytical work on the 
socioeconomic  impact  assessment  of  COVID-19  in  Uzbekistan,  (ii) prioritized  economic 
management policies and sector and thematic strategies that are prepared or updated based on 
the findings of the analytical work on COVID-19, and (iii) products developed to provide sustained 
support on institutional strengthening and to enable the MOEDPR to lead and facilitate economic 
management functions effectively.                            
              
14.  Output 1: Knowledge products and analytical work on the socioeconomic impact 
assessment  of  COVID-19  in  Uzbekistan.  This  output  will  (i)  assess  the  socioeconomic

implications of the unfolding disruption caused by COVID-19, including effects of the crisis on 
women, and provide support10 to address GBV during the pandemic; (ii) identify emerging trends 
from the government’s anti-crisis measures to mitigate negative effects on the population; and (iii) 
propose country-specific transformative pathways to build back better, and accelerate reforms 
once the disruption stabilizes in the medium term. The assessment will cover the external and 
internal  transmission  channels  affecting  the  country’s  macroeconomic  situation,  and  the 
socioeconomic impacts on the population. It will assess effects on the sectors and labor markets, 
spatial disparities, poverty and food security issues, adequacy of social protection systems and 
efficacy of the government’s anti-crisis measures. A health sector analysis will also be undertaken 
as part of the TA activities, and its findings will inform the overall assessment.    
 
15.  Output 2: Prioritized economic management policies, and sector and thematic 
strategies prepared or updated. This output consists of knowledge products to be prepared 
under each of the prioritized economic management policies, and sector and thematic strategies. 
Indicative areas for ADB support include the concept for inclusive socioeconomic development, 
approaches for industrial policy development, labor and skills development, access to finance, 
and the rolling out poverty reduction programs. Vision 2030 is the government’s flagship approach 
for socioeconomic development to ensure a long-term sustainable improvement in people’s well-
being, food security, and to develop the economy. The planned Vision 2030 work will be informed 
by the findings from background analyses undertaken for the MOEDPR in other areas, such as 
the COVID-19 socioeconomic impact assessment, approaches for industrial development, and 
poverty  reduction.  The  work  on  industrial  policy  development  will  cover  the  analysis  of 
international benchmarks on how selected economies have successfully transitioned from being 
commodity exporters to more value-added industrial outcomes. It will identify lessons from 
previous industrial policy efforts and highlight the risks of taking a heavy approach on the role of 
the state that impede private sector development. The outputs will include the evidence base as 
to which segments could be sequenced for future public and private investments. It will cover 
inclusive job creation schemes, diversified growth, infrastructure development, private sector 
growth, and regional connectivity.   
 
16.  Output 3: Sustained support on institutional strengthening provided to enable the 
MOEDPR lead and facilitate economic management functions effectively. This output could 
take the form of action plans for institutional strengthening that identify and demarcate roles and 
responsibilities between the MOEDPR and other ministries on areas such as investment policy, 
and public investment management; or through policy notes on the role of the MOEDPR in guiding 
SOE reforms with different policy options available to the MOEDPR to improve operational 
efficiency of SOEs. ADB and the MOEDPR will undertake periodic consultations to identify further 
areas or topics in economic management policies, sector and thematic strategies, institutional 
strengthening, and capacity development support through the TA.  ADB will offer need-based 
support either through consultants who provide direct support to the ministry; or diagnostic work 
including rapid assessments on specific topics; training; or standalone workshops and roundtable 
meetings on prioritized topics. 
 
 
10 This support will include (i) design and implementation of a multimedia communication campaign targeted at people 
at risk of GBV, victims and their families, with messages designed to prevent violence in the context of COVID-19; 
(ii) training program on emergency responses to GBV cases; (iii) training of staff in crisis centers on stress 
management and mental health; and (iv) GBV counselling, legal information, and referral links to hotline and 
multidisciplinary services.

C.  Cost and Financing 
  
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $650,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF–6).  The  key  expenditure  items  are  listed  in 
Appendix 2.11  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, 
logistics and administrative support and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The MOEDPR will be the executing agency and will implement the TA in close consultation 
with ADB. The MOEDPR has formed a working group to guide and coordinate the activities 
supported by the TA. Individual consultants, both international and national, will be recruited. ADB 
will also recruit suitable resource persons as needed. The implementation arrangements are 
summarized in the table.

and/or staff instructions.12 National consultants will also be recruited as part of ADB’s wider

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Uzbekistan for the Assessment of Socioeconomic Impacts of COVID-19 and 
Institutional Strengthening for Policy Responses, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Knowledge products and analytical work on COVID-19 socioeconomic impact assessment 
1.1. ADB and MOEDPR teams attend inception meeting to agree on a conceptual framework for a 
COVID-19 socioeconomic impact assessment and draft outline for the final report. 
1.2. The MOEDPR identifies partner research institute/s to collaborate with COVID-19 assessment work, 
particularly data collection, and the survey instrument and methodologies to be used. 
1.3. Prepare COVID-19 socioeconomic impact assessment (including gender issues) and health sector 
assessment, with identification of key findings, issues, lessons, and policy recommendations.  
 
2.  Prioritized economic management policies and sector and thematic strategies prepared or 
updated 
2.1. ADB and the MOEDPR attend periodic meetings to identify priority topics for ADB support and 
monitor implementation.  
2.2. Select international consultants and experts on the identified topic; complete inception meeting at 
the start of each ADB-supported analytical work product to agree on the outputs, focus of analytical 
work, prospective areas for policy recommendations, and timelines.  
2.3. Prepare  knowledge  products,  including  policy  notes,  with  a  limited  set  of  actionable 
recommendations.  
 
3.  Sustained support on institutional strengthening provided to the MOEDPR 
3.1  ADB and the MOEDPR jointly identify approaches for institutional strengthening in specific areas 
and topics, including the scope, timeline, and areas for policy recommendations.  
3.2  Select suitable international experts to formulate policy options for the roles of the MOEDPR, based 
on international experience, to plan and manage economic management and poverty reduction 
efforts.  
3.3  Implement time-bound action plans on institutional strengthening and capacity development on the 
interface of the MOEDPR with other ministries, in areas such as investment policy, planning, and 
programming. 
3.4   Highlight capacity gaps and provide capacity development, including through workshops, to 
achieve the most effective distribution of functions and operational efficiency across the different 
state bodies.
